 Why not look at these things as questions? Or as problems to be solved or resolved? 
 
 Identify the problem. - "What's the real question we're facing here?"
 Define the context. - "What are the facts and circumstances that frame this problem?"
 Enumerate choices. - "What are our most plausible three or four options?"
 Analyze options. - "What is our best course of action, all things considered?"
 List reasons explicitly. - "Let's be clear: Why we are making this particular choice?"
 Self-correct. - "Okay, let's look at it again. What did we miss?"

 If you're speaking about the bipartisan  passage of the Financial Services Modernization Act  in 1999?
 
 
Oct.-Nov. 1999 Congress passes Financial Services Modernization Act 
 
 After 12 attempts in 25 years, Congress finally repeals Glass-Steagall, rewarding financial companies for more than 20 years and $300 million worth of lobbying efforts. Supporters hail the change as the long-overdue demise of a Depression-era relic. 
 
 On Oct. 21, with the House-Senate conference committee deadlocked after marathon negotiations, the main sticking point is partisan bickering over the bill's effect on the Community Reinvestment Act, which sets rules for lending to poor communities. Sandy Weill calls President Clinton in the evening to try to break the deadlock after Senator Phil Gramm, chairman of the Banking Committee, warned Citigroup lobbyist Roger Levy that Weill has to get White House moving on the bill or he would shut down the House-Senate conference. Serious negotiations resume, and a deal is announced at 2:45 a.m. on Oct. 22. Whether Weill made any difference in precipitating a deal is unclear. 
 
 On Oct. 22, Weill and John Reed issue a statement congratulating Congress and President Clinton, including 19 administration officials and lawmakers by name. The House and Senate approve a final version of the bill on Nov. 4, and Clinton signs it into law later that month. 
 
 Just days after the administration (including the Treasury Department) agrees to support the repeal, Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin, the former co-chairman of a major Wall Street investment bank, Goldman Sachs, raises eyebrows by accepting a top job at Citigroup as Weill's chief lieutenant. The previous year, Weill had called Secretary Rubin to give him advance notice of the upcoming merger announcement. When Weill told Rubin he had some important news, the secretary reportedly quipped, "You're buying the government?" 
 http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/wallstreet/weill/demise. html

 
 There has been a chipping away at the corrective measures (Glass-Steagall) put into place after the first Great Depression. & then even before that, there was Reagan (perhaps unwittingly?) orchestrating the savings-and-loan scandal of the 1980's: 
 
 
Most emblematic of the Reaganite attitude toward government was the savings-and-loan scandal. The president's advisors had convinced him that if he would only deregulate the thrift industry, a gigantic bonanza of growth and investment was sure to follow. His sunny quip when he signed the deregulation bill in 1982 was typical Reagan: "All in all, I think we've hit the jackpot." There's no reason to doubt he sincerely believed that with government shoved aside, everyone would prosper. The best reckoning of the costs of his benign intentions is a trillion dollars.
 Reagan without sentimentality - Salon.com

 "Decades after the civil rights movement, the income gap between black and white families has grown, says a new study that tracked the incomes of some 2,300 families for more than 30 years."
 Income gap between black, white families grows - Business - Stocks & economy - msnbc.com
 
 Equality in America is going down the toilet. There is plenty of wealth to go around but I guess Americans would rather see the rich get richer while the poor get poorer and millions remain unemployed. Equality is "socialist" according to the tea partiers and their ilk.

 
 These things sometimes remind me of the paradoxical thinking involved in the states' rights arguments re: Plantation economy. That is, they had no problem using the federal government's powers when it came to imploring the federal government to protect & promote the interests of the Plantation economy; HOWEVER they invoked states' rights rhetoric when attempting to restrict federal power when it's against the interest of the Plantation economy? What the ? 
 
 Similar to the paradoxical thinking involved in the present day when the corporatists (& their supporters) want the federal government to stay out of the special interests of the Corporate World Order (NO Government intervention, corrective measures, oversight, regulation, etc.). YET they are more than willing to accept bailouts from the very same government. Hhhmmm. 
 
 People have been speaking about "Too big to fail" & "Socialism for corporations (& by proxy, for the wealthiest classes) & capitalism for the poor & middle classes" since the Great Depression. What IS new is the removal of government regulations put in place after some of the causes of the Great Depression were analyzed. 
 
 One thing that hasn't changed much is human nature.
COBHC

For two reasons: One, Bush's spent a lot more than Obama, and two, we're still spending a lot of money on the wars that Bush started.

 
 Wasteful spending is wasteful spending. Theft is theft, whether you steal a trillion dollars or a candy bar, you can't call it anything other than "theft."
 
 
Like I said, I'm not an economist. But from what I remember, isn't government spending what nearly brought us out of the depression?

 
 A half-truth Obama supporters like to use. There was absolutely nothing that ended the great depression that was comparable to Obama's stimulus package. The U.S. Military's demand for weapons put companies back in business, providing people with jobs. The money the Government spent was used to buy American-made products, thus the money went to the American people. It was not used to buy foreign products or pay of debts to foreign countries. Also, as far as I know, the government didn't have any special programs to raise money, other than war bonds. 
 
 

 That's because the effects of Bush's economic mistakes are still being felt.

 
 Prove it. And while you're at it, explain why Obama's policies are so much better, or so much different for that matter.
 
 
I didn't see you mention Bush.

 
 How does that translate to "Bush doesn't deserve any blame?"
 
 
It looks to me like the fiscal stimulus played a major role in reducing the depth of the recession. 650,000 jobs have been created or saved by the Stimulus fund.

 
 You think that'll generate a trillion dollars? I'd also like to mention that much of the stimulus money will ultimately end up in the pockets of foreign people. Not helping us here in America.
 Examples of Wasted Obama Stimulus Money in North Carolina | Political-Politics
 
 
 Remember last year when we had to pass the stimulus package immediately, or unemployment would go to 8.5%? Well, unemployment peaked so far at over 10%, and the nearly 800 billion dollars that made up the stimulus has been used just like a typical [Bush-era] big government spending spree.
 
 
 
The economy is in chaos right now. Why is it in chaos? Because of Bush. He made it plummet, and Obama is being blamed for it.

 
 Once again, prove it.
 
 
And how do you know that skyrocket can't be attributed to the damage Bush had done? Simple because he wasn't sitting in the Oval office anymore?

 
 Because you haven't yet explained how Bush can be blamed for Obama's waste of money.
 
 
No, it's still reasonable to say that the unemployment rate would be even higher if the stimulus package wasn't passed.

 
 http://www.lesjones.com/2009/05/12/unemployment-numbers-worse-than-projected/
 It's not quite as well as the "expert doctor" predicted. In fact, it seems that the unemployment rate is higher than the Obama Administration predicted would be without the stimulus package. 
 
 http://www.lesjones.com/2009/05/12/unemployment-numbers-worse-than-projected/
 
 http://www.lesjones.com/www/images/posts/stimulus-vs-unemployment-april.gif
 
 
Obama was trying to fix the economy, not shoot it in the heart, which is why that is a false analogy.
 

 
 Odd. I remember your analogy:
 But it wasn't. What you're doing is charging a doctor who failed to save a patient shot six times in the heart with murder rather than the shooter.
 
 When I used the exact same argument you used right there, you said:
 I don't care what his intentions were. He screwed everything up, bigtime. As the president he should know better.
 
 The analogy I used was valid unless you think Bush's intention was to cause economic difficulty. If Bush's programs and spending didn't solve any problems, I don't know what makes you sure Obama's programs and spending will.
 
 
No, you don't. 
 

 
 I do, since I haven't seen any evidence to convince me otherwise.
 
 
Really? Because I think it's called something else.

 
 That's an example of a government program, not something causing unemployment. I'm also pretty convinced that Obama would go to war with someone if 9-11 happened in 2010 rather than 2001, so you're not helping yourself.
 
 
You mean aside from the housing crisis, the Iraq war, the massive deficit, awarding the rich with tax cuts, and beginning the cycle of inflation and unemployment? If that's not "catastrophic" to you then I don't know what is.

 
 I meant "if Bush is causing current unemployment rates, then why did the effects wait conveniently until the stimulus bill was passed?"
 
 
]We saw the effects throughout the beginning and end of his term as well as after. Citing a sudden spike in the unemployment rate (a number that is temperamental and hard to predict) as proof of Obama's incompetence is flimsy at best.

 
 Then why don't you explain how Bush has caused unemployment?
Shooterandproud

Wasteful spending is wasteful spending. Theft is theft, whether you steal a trillion dollars or a candy bar, you can't call it anything other than "theft."

 
 Money spent on improving the economy is not a "candy bar".
 
 
 
A half-truth Obama supporters like to use. There was absolutely nothing that ended the great depression that was comparable to Obama's stimulus package. The U.S. Military's demand for weapons put companies back in business, providing people with jobs. The money the Government spent was used to buy American-made products, thus the money went to the American people. It was not used to buy foreign products or pay of debts to foreign countries. Also, as far as I know, the government didn't have any special programs to raise money, other than war bonds.

 
 And tell me, why did we borrow so much from foreign countries? What was it that we needed to fund?
 
 
 
 
Prove it. And while you're at it, explain why Obama's policies are so much better, or so much different for that matter.

 
 I don't need to prove something I didn't claim. The war was not one of Bush's "economic policies", or at least I hope to God it wasn't.
 
 
How does that translate to "Bush doesn't deserve any blame?"

 
 Because you're not giving Bush any blame.
 
 
You think that'll generate a trillion dollars? I'd also like to mention that much of the stimulus money will ultimately end up in the pockets of foreign people. Not helping us here in America.
 Examples of Wasted Obama Stimulus Money in North Carolina | Political-Politics
 
 
 Remember last year when we had to pass the stimulus package immediately, or unemployment would go to 8.5%? Well, unemployment peaked so far at over 10%, and the nearly 800 billion dollars that made up the stimulus has been used just like a typical [Bush-era] big government spending spree.
 

 
 I didn't say the Stimulus was a good thing nor did I say Obama was not to blame. I said Bush was more to blame than Obama.
 
 
Once again, prove it.

 
 The economy began it's plummet under Bush.
 
 PPI: Bush vs. Clinton: An Economic Performance Index by Robert D. Atkinson and Julie Hutto
 
 
Because you haven't yet explained how Bush can be blamed for Obama's waste of money.

 
 That's because I didn't. Bush's waste of money was worse.
 
 
http://www.lesjones.com/2009/05/12/unemployment-numbers-worse-than-projected/
 It's not quite as well as the "expert doctor" predicted. In fact, it seems that the unemployment rate is higher than the Obama Administration predicted would be without the stimulus package. 
 
 http://www.lesjones.com/2009/05/12/unemployment-numbers-worse-than-projected/
 
 http://www.lesjones.com/www/images/posts/stimulus-vs-unemployment-april.gif
 

 
 The unemployment rate is very hard to predict. Forgive me if I don't take your "predictions" seriously.
 
 
 
Odd. I remember your analogy:
 But it wasn't. What you're doing is charging a doctor who failed to save a patient shot six times in the heart with murder rather than the shooter.
 
 When I used the exact same argument you used right there, you said:
 I don't care what his intentions were. He screwed everything up, bigtime. As the president he should know better.
 
 The analogy I used was valid unless you think Bush's intention was to cause economic difficulty. If Bush's programs and spending didn't solve any problems, I don't know what makes you sure Obama's programs and spending will.

 
 I was proving why your analogy was false, not why Obama should be vindicated. You've nearly spent this entire post telling me why I think Obama is the greatest thing for the economy since sliced bread, which I don't. Stop putting words in my mouth.
 
 
I do, since I haven't seen any evidence to convince me otherwise.

 
 I haven't seen any evidence to convince me that the tooth fairy doesn't exist.
 
 
That's an example of a government program, not something causing unemployment. I'm also pretty convinced that Obama would go to war with someone if 9-11 happened in 2010 rather than 2001, so you're not helping yourself.

 
 Of course he would. But would he go to war with another random, unrelated country and justify it with false claims? I don't think so.
 
 One president wastes money on hurting people, the other "wastes" money on helping people. I think I know the lesser of the two evils.
 
 
I meant "if Bush is causing current unemployment rates, then why did the effects wait conveniently until the stimulus bill was passed?"

 
 They didn't. The unemployment rate climbed during Bush too. Right now, the unemployment rate is 3% higher than it was under bush. A 3% increase can easily be attributed to other factors. The unemployment rate climbs and falls all the time. I wouldn't be so quick to blame the evil liberals.
 
 
Then why don't you explain how Bush has caused unemployment?

 
 Didn't I just do that?
COBHC

Money spent on improving the economy is not a "candy bar".

 
 Did you forget the other part of the analogy? A trillion dollars is.
 
 

 And tell me, why did we borrow so much from foreign countries? What was it that we needed to fund?

 
 I myself would like to know that.
 
 
I don't need to prove something I didn't claim. The war was not one of Bush's "economic policies", or at least I hope to God it wasn't.

 
 "That's because the effects of Bush's economic mistakes are still being felt."
 
 What didn't you claim? For the record, I sort of agree with that statement. However, I question your confidence that Obama will fix the economy, or your "skepticism" that he will fail to do so. I also question your viewpoint that Obama's policies have not yet had visible effect on the economy.
 
 
Because you're not giving Bush any blame.

 
 Says who? Haven't I been saying if government spending (under a past leader) causes problems, then more government spending (under a current or future leader) won't fix them?
 
 
I didn't say the Stimulus was a good thing nor did I say Obama was not to blame. I said Bush was more to blame than Obama.

 
 In less than two years, Obama has raised the national debt by about $3,000,000,000,000. That's more than a quarter of how much Bush raised it in ten years. Like Symbiote said, Obama is like Bush on steroids. At this rate, the US National debt will more than double by 2016.
 
 
The economy began it's plummet under Bush.
 
 PPI: Bush vs. Clinton: An Economic Performance Index by Robert D. Atkinson and Julie Hutto

 
 Who says otherwise?
 
 
That's because I didn't. Bush's waste of money was worse.

 
 If you're talking sheer quantity of money, that will change if Obama keeps his spending habit and gets re-elected. Obama has already increased the national debt for his time in office more than Bush has.
 
 
The unemployment rate is very hard to predict. Forgive me if I don't take your "predictions" seriously.

 
 It's based on simple logic. If government spending caused a problem, more government spending will only make it worse.
 
 
I was proving why your analogy was false, not why Obama should be vindicated.

 
 Then why was Bush a "shooter" and Obama an "expert doctor?" You said Bush "shot the US economy six times" (if my analogy is invalid, then so is that one). I simply pointed out that if Bush "shot the economy", then Obama simply "tried to save it" by shooting it more. The analogy is valid unless you think Bush deliberately caused economic trouble, and that Obama used different methods to try to save it.
 
 Or perhaps you think the analogy is only invalid when used against Obama. emoticon_rolleyes
 
 
You've nearly spent this entire post telling me why I think Obama is the greatest thing for the economy since sliced bread, which I don't. Stop putting words in my mouth.
 

 
 You take your own advice and stop trying to make it sound like I'm saying Bush is innocent of causing economic difficulty. I've been saying that if government spending and programs (under Bush) caused problems, then more government spending and programs (under anyone) won't fix them.
 
 But now that you've mentioned it, I got a feeling you'll be voting for the Democratic Candidate in 2012. I got a feeling you don't have any specific ideas for fixing the economy, and I got a feeling that you don't support any third parties that you think would benefit the economy. Also, I don't think you're skeptical about democratic presidents. In fact, I think you're very confident that a democrat (possibly Barack Obama) will fix the economy.
 
 

 I haven't seen any evidence to convince me that the tooth fairy doesn't exist.

 
 So we should assume that she does? I repeat myself: I believe that Obama is responsible for the current increase in economic difficulties because I haven't seen any evidence to convince me otherwise. I just hear "well maybe Bush is responsible!" Sorry, but you can't blame increasing economic difficulties on Bush forever. The longer you use that argument, the more ridiculous it becomes.
 
 
Of course he would. But would he go to war with another random, unrelated country and justify it with false claims? I don't think so.

 
 I was expecting you to use that argument. 
 
 The most important thing about that claim is that it's irrelevant. Whether he went to war with the right people or not, money would still be spent. Terrorist groups are equally as resilient whether they were responsible for 9-11 or not. The economy in the US would be no different had Bush attacked the right people.
 
 But now that you've mentioned it, what makes you think Obama wouldn't do such a thing? Because he's a nice guy? emoticon_rolleyes
 
 
One president wastes money on hurting people, the other "wastes" money on helping people. I think I know the lesser of the two evils.

 
 Once again, you're making it sound like Bush intentionally caused economic difficulty.
 
 One guy hits people on the head with a hammer to hurt them, and the next guy hits them harder with the hammer to help them. There may be "change," but that change will not be the result of hitting people with a hammer.
 
 Originally posted by Shooterandproud: I don't care what his intentions were. He screwed everything up, bigtime. As the president he should know better.
 
 
They didn't. The unemployment rate climbed during Bush too. Right now, the unemployment rate is 3% higher than it was under bush. A 3% increase can easily be attributed to other factors. The unemployment rate climbs and falls all the time. I wouldn't be so quick to blame the evil liberals.

 
 What? Leftists were rejoicing and praising Obama when 650,000 were supposedly created, for a total change in the unemployment rate of 0.2%, but 3% isn't significant? Three percent is 9,750,000 jobs. Not nearly an insignificant number that can be attributed to random fluctuations.
 
 MID-DAY UPDATE: Unemployment rate drops. Sounds good. It isn't. | News In Brief | Marketplace from American Public Media
